title: Do you prefer writing fiction to non-fiction, and if so, why? - Quora

response.answer_text: Fiction, definitely. Although I will admit, for all the fictional creative writing classes I’ve taken while attending college, several of my short stories were inspired by non-fictional events which I then re-wrote and slightly edited for the purposes of storytelling. In many of my other stories, I will take real-life events and experiences and fictionalize them to be more entertaining, more suspenseful, or just more interesting in general. So while I may be writing something fiction, its inspiration gives it relevancy and believability for the reader to accept. I also feel like there’s a kind of freedom that comes with writing fiction, as evidenced by the wide variety of genres (dystopian fiction, science fiction, fantasy fiction, etc.), although this can make writing more challenging. You have the freedom to do anything, be anyone, but the challenges are dictated by the universe you set the story in. For example, a fictional story that takes place in our reality still has to obey certain rules like physics (you can’t have people jumping off buildings and not falling), the criminal law (someone who commits a high-profile crime will likely try to cover their tracks), and probability to be real (a seven-year-old becoming an instant billionaire by selling lemonade? Not likely), to name a few. Of course, there are thousands of other stories not set in our reality that don’t have to obey these rules specifically, but the other ones created by the authors to ensure a sense of believability. While this does have the potential to lead to a plothole (because an author forgot to take a rule into account), it is sometimes the inevitable side effect of fictional writing, but often we as readers can suspend our belief to overlook these flaws because the majority of the story is successful and enjoyable. Non-fiction stories can certainly achieve the same entertainment that a fictional story can, but from a writing standpoint, the appeal of letting my imagination take over for those few fleeting moments while my fingers are barely able to keep up over a keyboard is perhaps the best escape from reality.

I write both fiction and non-fiction. I say I enjoy writing fiction more than non-fiction. I enjoy the freedom for creativity fiction provides. But when I have finished a purely fiction story, I rarely end by saying, “Wow.” The fact is, I have written a couple of stories which ended with the above uttered “Wow.” What was it about those stories that grabbed my emotions so strongly? Within that story was something real I was relating to. I wrote a historical fiction piece about the shootings at Kent State University on May 4, 1970. Some will recall that horrific day when the United States National Guard opened fire on students protesting the war in Vietnam and the invasion of Cambodia. Four students were killed and nine were injured. I was thirteen years old at the time. It made an impact. When I fictionalized that story, I was there in my mind. I saw the violence, not on a television screen but in my mind and memory. Fiction which capitalizes on my own experiences and emotions is what makes me, the humble author, end the story with, “Wow.” The Message: Historical Flash Fiction by cam

I used to teach literature teenagers, and one of the most frustrating things was to hear them dismiss fiction as being “not real.” The fact is, fiction—genre fiction or general fiction—is an attempt to give the human experience narrative. Whether the characters are fictional or not does not change the fact that they are “real” to our intellect and emotions as we are reading or writing them. And just because a story is dubbed “non-fiction” doesn’t mean a fictional narrative hasn’t been superimposed on real events—anybody who has ever heard a compulsive liar narrate a story in which she was right and the rest of the world was out to get her understands what I mean. Because fiction isn’t “documented fact” it often gets a bad rap—people like my students assume that it’s easy to “just make stuff up” and more difficult to “tell it like it is.” This is, in fact, the exact opposite of what’s true. Building a world—even a world in contemporary fiction requires a real use of intelligence and creativity. Again, look at your compulsive liar—it would have been a lot harder for her to write a fictional romance in which someone NOT like her is the heroine than it is for her to talk about the time someone tried to screw her over at work. I’ve written a lot about this—here’s one of my more recent guest blog posts: Genre Ripples by Amy Lane but I’ve strayed from the question. Which one do I prefer? Fiction. Fiction to me is more real, more intellectually and emotionally engaging, and more fulfilling than nonfiction. I blog five nights a week and it’s the easiest part of my writing regime. When I have extra time—and extra creativity—buzzing through my veins, I write fan fiction or ficlets of my own characters. That’s not nearly so easy—but I love it so much more because it takes a bigger part of my soul.

I enjoy writing fiction, but I got my start writing non-fiction as a journalist, and it's key to dispelling the idea that writing is some romantic, mystical exercise. It's work. Hard work. And unless you put in the work, you have nothing. I don't know why we recognize non-fiction as work, but we have these lofty ideas about fiction, as if the muses must visit us and dictate stories in flashes of divine inspiration. You're never going to hear a newspaper or magazine writer claim she has writer’s block, or that she's waiting for inspiration. Professionals can't afford to do that, and they know they'd get laughed out of the newsroom if they began talking about writing the way fiction writers do. Non-fiction also forces writers to develop research skills, study human nature, and really listen to the way people speak, which is crucial to writing believable dialog.

I prefer fiction because you can create anything, nothing has to be factual. I have written books that the settings were in different cities, Dallas, Reno Nevada, Iowa, Miami, Philly, Rhode Island, DC (which is my city) . I choose my cities without a lot of thought , although I never want to anger the citizens of any particular city with being inaccurate with information. I worked as a Travel Agent briefly so I am familiar with amenities of many chosen cities. Google is there for research as well. You have a lot of leave-way with fiction writing because you are stating, this novel is not based upon any persons or people that you are writing about. Love that!!

Non-fiction. However, I wish I had the creativity and talent to write fiction. Not everyone can write fiction, and I’m one of those people. My ‘why’ is based strictly on observation and I could be entirely wrong. Some people are great storytellers. But others are journalists. Ask a journalist to write fiction. Most can’t do it. Ask Stephen King to write nonfiction for the next 10 years, and his paycheck will drop (King on Writing is the exception to the rule here). Accordingly, being the journalist-like writer is easier for me. I’m not saying I’m good at it. But I find it easy to crank out 1500 to 2000 words when writing blog posts.

The storytelling plays a major role in the narration. It doesn’t matter whether it to be a Fiction or not along as it seems persuasive. I knew a writer who always writes the ‘tail-piece’ very well. The last paragraph of a chapter that makes readers turn the next page or else bookmark the position with a great feeling. Non-fiction is about the drama that the author creates with his experiences. A man walking on the street... A tall, young man with improper gestures kept his one injured hand steady, while the other swaying to pace along the street... A small boy caught the figure of a heavy man thumping the ground while passing through... It was the pity that he wanted to see in the faces of the neighborhood, murmuring about how a good man like him could get injured, thought to consult him for any support at the sight of his injured hand... The author uses fictional narratives to increase the intensity of Non-fictional writing. While the Fiction lies in the narration of the writer. Keep writing :)

I prefer writing Non Fiction. In fact, I believe that when you write true stories it imparts more strong impact on the readers and when a reader knows that the story or the book he/she is reading has been based on the true story, he does it remember, he takes it as a lesson which fictional stories are unable to do so. Non fictional writings are generally the result of the experiences which cause other people to learn new social interactions, psychology and history etc. It expands the very minds of the people and make them more receptive to the natural world. It keeps them from flourishing in the fantasies and allows them to live in the real World. Non fictional stories exposes a person to the real World. They know that good and bad is the part of this World.. They become aware that every person’s life has ups and downs. Sometimes you are misjudged, whereas at other times you just can’t fulfil other’s people needs. Thank You

I definitely have a preference while I’m writing. When I’m writing nonfiction I invariably reach a point where the research has mostly been done and collected and I have referred back to it for the umpty-seventh time and I’m thinking, I wish I was just making this up because then I could make it come out the way I want and forget this pile of notes and books full of book marks. Just as certainly, when I’m writing fiction, I’m going to hit a spot where a character doesn’t want to do what I want them to (a problem requiring character background correction) or I can’t decide which of several possible directions to take the story and I’m thinking, I wish this was nonfiction so I could just look it up and go on.

Yes, I would say so. Writing non-fiction always makes me think, “So who do you think you are, anyway, taking it upon yourself to lecture people you’ve never met about things they could find out perfectly well for themselves?” (That’s actually the main reason I like this site; when I know someone’s actually asking a particular question, I feel far less compunction about answering it publicly.) Whereas, when I’m making up the story myself, there does seem to be a good reason why I should be the one to tell everyone about it.

I love writing fiction because I can make everything up. I can make my own rules. I am the master of all that is or was or ever will be in my world (s). I feel like it's simpler but also more complicated. Simple because I don't necessarily have to research anything if it's otherworldly enough. But difficult because I as the writer and creater have to think of everything and then remember it all for later in the story. There are pros and cons to both. But my heart will always belong to fiction.

Fiction is by far the most interesting form of otherworldly, mind blowing and most fulfilling form of adventure this planet ever has to offer. I love its creative capacity, the possibility of parallel realities, other worlds, galaxies, solar systems and universes, with all their fantastic life forms, magical technologies, advanced social structures, and supreme intelligence that borders on faster than light kinetics and telekinesis, wordless communication and teleportation, time travel and dimensional travel. I love the DREAM, that makes me THINK and FEEL, ANALYZE, and question this LIFE. There’s nothing like it in all the world. Fiction, for me, is a doorway to fantastic possibilities, the ultimate adventure. :-)

FICTION… by far. I have never been published, I don’t work in anyway that requires me to write anything… I haven’t finished a story that I’ve started in over 15 years… That one got destroyed in a move so… Yeah… I don’t write, in the classic sense… But I do write as purely a way to get the ideas out of my head, because everything inspires me… Someday I hope to integrate many of the people I’ve created characters for into one big story… Until then, I’m still writing characters, and getting bored at the utter mediocrity of the stories I keep trying to force them into, then setting them aside.

I enjoy researching fiction, building worlds, and developing characters. Writing fiction that anyone would want to read is a skill that seems to escape me. So, that being the case, I must say that I prefer non-fiction. That way, I tend to like what I write, and customers are willing to pay the invoice.

Fiction. I like creating characters and plot that help humanize real world issues. Fiction creates empathy in readers via attachment to characters in a way that a lot of nonfiction doesn’t. I like that good fiction will stay with a reader for a long time, and help shape how we see the world. Nonfiction can do the same things, but I often find nonfiction more focused on academics and proving its points rather than building human connection.

Did you ever see a video anywhere, The reader opens a book and after just reading a line, the characters just spring to life and everything unfolds visually. That is Fiction to me. Be it reading or writing something. It is as good as your imagination wants it to be. Anything is possible. A spaceship in the middle of a Indian village. yes..why not. Let them even guard a secret. My advice…… “Go Crazy”

I generally prefer to read non-fiction (for its educational value), but I prefer to write fiction, because I can create my own reality, over which I have total control. I can place some of my own characteristics, as well as those of others I know, into my characters, to make them more believable and personal. It’s a form of catharsis for me.

I will prefer writing fiction reason being we constantly live a life which is real and we have to face it every single day and all we want is an escape sometime and that's when writing fiction helps. You can just imagine whatever you want, you can create a world of your own thoughts like you want it nobody can give you advice on that no rules for you.

Definitely fiction. There’s too much self-help & professional development blogs in the media today. The problem is that they’re trying to sell you a prescriptive solution, when in reality, only you yourself know what’s best for your life. I prefer letting readers decide what’s considered right & wrong in their own lives, but provide a canvas and in depth, multi-dimensional characters to guide the decision making in life.

Fiction. In a fiction story, I get to be the 'god' of my universe. I'm not saying I have any kind of religious significance, but instead I get to control what happens. I build it, I make it's creatures, I create it's people, I control events. It makes me feel powerful, since I control anything and everything in my universe. :)

Fiction. The ability to create entire worlds without much constraint is enjoyable. Plus, it can be really entertaining to wiggle in references/nods to historical events and other stories, or even games and films.

I like telling stories, taking people and imagining lives for them, imagining conflict, and then it’s like sitting back and watching the story unfold in real time as I write it. But I have written a lot of poetry also, which I do particularly enjoy.

Both but I always intertwine them accidentally and then never get around to publishing it. That is because I fear readers won’t understand
I prefer fiction but the challenge of writing interesting non-fiction is engaged when I blog…
